‘No excuses’: Frustrated council members press Richard’s Disposal over garbage failures
BY SARAH RAVITS
Jan 6, 2023
A Richard's Disposal truck 
PHOTO BY DAVID GRUNFELD/ THE TIMES-PICAYUNE
Facebook
Twitter
Email
Print
Copy article link
Save
Frustrated New Orleans City Council members are demanding swift action from Mayor LaToya Cantrell’s administration to resolve Richard’s Disposal’s ongoing failure to haul off residential waste. 
Council members Freddie King, Joe Giarrusso and Lesli Harris issued a joint statement Friday, calling on the Department of Sanitation to come up with new plans, citing escalating public health concerns and a declining quality of life for fed-up residents who have complained for months about missed pickups and overflowing, festering bins.   
“There can be no excuses,” said Giarrusso, who represents District A. “The trash needs to be collected. This is urgent. This is about delivering basic services. This is a public health issue. The solution is self-evident: Immediate supplementation must be provided with a focus on the missed routes.”  
The call for action is part of the Council’s ongoing push to get waste management on track in New Orleans.
Although overshadowed by the controversy surrounding Metro Services' trash collection woes, Richard's record has also been inadequate for much of the last year and a half following Hurricane Ida.  
“The lack of basic trash and recycling pickup service is unacceptable,” District B's Harris said. “It’s time for the City to get to the bottom of this issue. The Department of Sanitation must announce a plan to stabilize trash collection across Service Area 2.” 
For months, residents in the service area — which encompasses large swaths of Uptown, Mid-City, Broadmoor, Gentilly, Ninth Ward and Algiers, have been in distress over the city’s failure to provide this basic municipal service. 
“We are still seeing a high volume of calls about missed trash and recycling collections in District C on both sides of the river,” said King. “This issue does not seem to be improving."  
As Carnival season kicks off, the council members emphasized the need for swift action as the city’s population is expected to swell with tourists and celebrations in the coming weeks.  
Harris, who chairs the council’s Quality of Life Committee, said, “it should not be the responsibility of residents to constantly report missed pickups."  
Cantrell's administration also acknowledged the problem Friday afternoon and issued a statement, saying they were confident that they will find a solution. "The City of New Orleans is aware of Richard's failure to live up to the demands of its contract," a spokesperson said. "The administration has been working toward a solution that will ensure the residents will receive the sanitations they pay for and that they deserve."  
This story has been updated with a statement from the Cantrell administration.
